messageBody:
"I know that some will argue that I should
use more mocks to reduce dependancies"

It depends on the situation. Sometimes creating a mock involves a lot of
effort.

It seems like we have 3 situations ?

1) Run all the tests in any order

2) Run these x tests in this y order and stop as soon as you hit the first
failure.

3) Tests that combine 1) and 2).

I am a newbie and haven't read/studied the doco carefully. So, I don't know
how easy it is to do 2).

"value in the concept of dependency"

Definitely !
-----Original Message-----
From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com]On Behalf Of
Mark Levison
Sent: Friday, January 20, 2006 9:41 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Unit 4.0 release candidate 2 Test ordering


There is however value in the concept of dependency. I've come across
situations where if one test failed then a number of other tests would be
guarenteed to fail. The failure of the latter tests would make it more
difficult to spot the root cause. I know that some will argue that I
should
use more mocks to reduce dependancies. But I have come across situations
where that just didn't do the trick.

Mark
